PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(i) the fringe benefits tax will place enormous cost increases on employers throughout Australia;
(ii) in so doing, the fringe benefits tax will raise the cost of employing labour particularly in remote locations and it will inevitably worsen the already high level of unemployment in Australia;
(iii) much of the cost of the tax will be carried by employees as employers reduce benefits; and
(iv) the cost of the tax will harm small business particularly as these businesses will be unable to pass on the costs of the tax and as a result many may be forced to close.
Your petitioners therefore call upon the Government to repeal this unfair tax before it damages Australian business and thereby reduces the standard of living of all Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax: Government Schools
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Whereas the fringe benefits tax will place a costly and unfair burden on independent schools.

The fringe benefits tax will have a most damaging impact upon schools which provide boarding accommodation for children as they are also required to provide accommodation for staff members to live in and supervise the boarders.

Independent schools have limited resources and this additional impost will ultimately have to be passed on to parents, many of whom are already heavily committed to the financing of their children's education.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Parliament to recognize that the future of Australia depends upon the education given to its children and to exempt schools from the operation of the fringe benefits tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread community concern about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia.
Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) Block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia and
(2) Ban the import of Cobalt-60 and Caesium 137 and Caesium 134 to be used to irradiate food products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prohibition of Exportation of Uranium to France Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

that the only activity now taking place in the South Pacific which the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty bans is the testing of nuclear weapons by France at Mururoa and that the export of uranium by Australia to France undermines the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:

urge the Government to adhere to the Australian Labor Party's policy, as set out in the Customs Amendment (Prohibition of the Exportation of Uranium to France) Bill which prohibits the supply of uranium to France until France stops testing nuclear weapons in the South Pacific.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitution Alteration Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. that the result of the recent Queensland State election, when the National Party received a comfort- able majority in Parliament with a bare 39% of the votes, violates the rights of a majority of citizens to elect a government of their choice; and
2. that consequently there is an urgent need for electoral and constitutional reform at Federal and State level.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should: Support the Constitution Alteration (Democratic Elections) 1985 Bill.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should ask the Federal Government to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bill of Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we support the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985, which will
protect individuals against violation of their rights by the impact of laws or by the actions of the government institutions;
be effective in implementing Australia's international obligations to properly secure fundamental rights and freedoms; and
provide an educative charter.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should support the passage of this Bill at an early date.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Military and Intelligence Facilities in Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains electronic communication facilities, operated by Australian and American personnel, that gives the United States the ability to pin-point Soviet nuclear submarines, hidden in the Oceans.

2. This would make it possible for U.S. killer-submarines to destroy all Soviet nuclear submarines, while the U.S. nuclear submarines launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
3. The ``joint U.S.-Australian'' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the ``joint Australian-U.S.'' electronic communication facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully showeth:

in order that Australia no longer take any part in the nuclear confrontation, that as the leases to the US Government of nuclear-connected military bases in Australia come up for periodic renewal, your Honourable House will see that all such agreements are cancelled.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the lease currently negotiable for the Pine Gap base not be approved when submitted to your Honourable House.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we ask the Government to renew the agreement with the US Government on the facilities at Pine Gap only on receiving from the US Government a written guarantee that it will take up whole-heartedly and in good faith the phased nuclear disarmament plan put forward by the Soviets earlier this year, for complete nuclear disarmament by the year 2000.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
There is a need for an Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation to give a firm legislative and financial basis for the SBS Network.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should: Pass Senator Vigor's Bill with all expediency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I remind the Minister of his comments on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio in Canberra this morning when, asked whether he accepted the findings of the Jones Inquiry into the Australian War Memorial that there had not been any misbehaviour by Air Vice-Marshal Flemming, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: There was misbehaviour in my view. There was misbehaviour.

If the Minister believes so strongly that misbehaviour has occurred, does he intend taking action against the Director under the existing law, which allows dismissal by the Governor-General on the grounds of misbehaviour? Does he agree that this would be fairer to Air Vice-Marshal Flemming than an attempt to amend the existing legislation in that, if the Director were dismissed for misbehaviour, he would have recourse to action for wrongful dismissal? In other words, does he agree that this course of action would at least give the Director a chance to establish, before a properly constituted body, who is right on the question of misbehaviour?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has always been an option available to the Minister and to the Government to exercise the section of the Australian War Memorial Act which would give the Governor-General the opportunity to dismiss the Director of the Australian War Memorial in accordance with the powers of that Act. It has not been my intention to exercise that option, not because I disagree with the possibility that that action would be successful, but because at the time at which the inquiries were continuing-they have been continuing for the last three months-it would have been prejudicial to the rights of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming to have done so. Therefore, any suggestion by honourable senators opposite that somehow I was engaged in a vendetta against Air Vice-Marshal Flemming does not bear any substance at all. I have indicated to my own Party, to the Government, and to the Australian War Memorial Council that that was an option that was always available and I did not feel obliged at that stage, when the inquiry was taking place, to avail myself of it. However, the Council has, on two occasions in recent days, required the Director not to report for work. He has defied that request and, in the opinion of some persons, that constitutes misbehaviour. He has also incurred a decision of the Council which has expressed no confidence in him and which has also suggested that the Government ought to amend the legislation so that the Council-I stress, the Council and not the Government-may, in its wisdom, seek to remove Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. That is a matter about which I am sure Senator Reid is aware.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been interviewed many times by the media in the last few days, and even in the last few hours, and I have indicated that that is a matter which is going before Cabinet today and that it is a matter of whether the Government agrees to the suggestion of the Council. If it does the Government will, of course, introduce legislation into the House of Representatives and in due course it will put it before the Senate for its consideration. However, if those options do not eventuate there is still a possibility that the Government may avail itself of the provision to which Senator Reid referred, but I am not prepared to canvass that seriously at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations been drawn to an article in the Australian this morning headlined `Hay vows UN move against compulsory trade unionism'-sic-in which there was a report of a speech made to the Western Australian Liberal Party's newest faction, the 500 Club? If so, can the Minister indicate what implications the proposals put forward by the New Right's Mr Andrew Hay would have for Australia's industrial relations system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have indeed seen the article to which Senator Cook refers. I think the headline in this case is an accurate summary of the main points made in Mr Hay's speech, or at least in the report of it in the newspaper, although it is wrong insofar as there is no such thing as compulsory unionism in the absolute sense in Australia-there are provisions for conscientious objectors to opt out of union membership-but that is the fault of Mr Hay rather than the fault of the newspaper. Mr Hay also made some comments about the present leadership of the Liberal Party, as the paper put it, by speculating about a challenge to the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. He said that the Opposition was like an Antarctic dog sled team-the head dog was doing his best but the rest of the dogs were yapping. That is probably an accurate assessment of what is going on in the Liberal Party. I think what really worries Mr Hay about it is that the head dog is not veering to the right quite as hard as Mr Hay would like him to, but no doubt with a few touch-ups from Mr Hay's whip he will do that-assuming he is still there if he needs to be.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of the effects of this policy being advocated by Mr Hay on the conciliation and arbitration system, the most important point to note is that, without registered organisations which can represent both employers and employees-and by represent I mean represent effectively insofar as they cover the great majority of the employees and employers who are respondents to an award-a conciliation and arbitration system simply becomes unworkable. So what Mr Hay would see as the abolition of compulsory unionism is, of course, were it to be done in the way that he wants it done, the abolition of the conciliation and arbitration system itself. That is an outcome, of course, which would suit Mr Hay and a number of other people on the extreme Right but it is not an outcome which would be good for the country.

It is also worth noting that a nearly closed shop arrangement-there is no such thing as a completely closed shop in terms of compulsory union membership for the reason I mentioned previously, which is that there are provisions for conscientious objectors to opt out of union membership-is absolutely essential. It has been a vital ingredient in ensuring the rapid demise of, say, the Builders Labourers Federation in New South Wales and Victoria following the deregistration of that organisation. If there were not other unions which were awarded coverage and whose members were then given preference in employment on building sites, the action taken by the State and Commonwealth governments against the BLF would not have been nearly as effective as it has.

Mr Hay was also advocating-going right over the top, as the far Right is always inclined to do, and trying to drag the Liberal Party dog sled team along with it-that logs of claims should be served on trade unions next year for an increase in working hours, the abolition of overtime and penalty rates, leave loadings and that sort of thing. First, there is a fundamental inconsistency in that if Mr Hay had his way there would be no Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on which to serve those logs of claims. Secondly, at a time when the union movement in general and the Australian Council of Trade Unions leadership in particular have shown an extraordinary degree of responsibility and self-discipline, an awareness of the national interest and a willingness to work for it, it would be provocative and highly counter-productive to add that sort of shopping list of complaints and grievances to the real problem, which is being addressed responsibly by the Government and the unions, of getting an effective wages policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs confirm that on 21 August he received a copy of the O'Connor report into allegations concerning the administration of the Australian War Memorial? Did the Minister request Memorial Council members Corcoran, Wright, McMullen, Fry, Darling and Pugh to attend a meeting that night in his office, the night before the full Council was to receive and consider the O'Connor report? Was such a meeting held and was the Chairman of the Council advised and invited to attend? Does the Minister agree that his purpose in bringing together these Council members, all of whom were appointed by the Hawke Government, was to seek their support for his determination to remove the Director of the Memorial?

—I recall the occasion to which Senator MacGibbon refers. I draw his attention to the fact that when I assumed the portfolio responsibility for the Australian War Memorial there was a very acute difference of opinion between the Chairman, Admiral Synnot, and Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. Members of the Council, both individually and collectively, approached me with respect to the problems which existed at the time. In the value judgment I made I did not seek to reappoint Admiral Synnot because I was convinced, on the basis of advice from existing members of the Australian War Memorial Council, that it was impossible for Admiral Synnot to have a continued association with Air Vice-Marshal Flemming. I freely concede that I was led into error by members of the Council who had approached me in regard to the matter. In retrospect I possibly made an error in not recommending the reappointment of Admiral Synnot. As it turned out, the problem was not Admiral Synnot; it was Air Vice- Marshal Flemming. When the matters began to come to a head in respect of some of the reports and information that had been conveyed to me, first by the Auditor-General and then in the O'Connor report, I naturally sought to advise members of the Council, some of whose advice I had previously accepted, of my concerns and misgivings about these matters. I see nothing wrong with taking that action.

—I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the Minister's answer that the meeting took place with a selected number of Council members. Would the Minister now confirm what subject was discussed? Was it a conspiracy to get rid of the Director?
—Order! The honourable senator is extending the benefit of a supplementary question.

—I have no difficulty in answering that question because over the last three months I have met many members of the Council, some of whom have had complete confidence in Air Vice-Marshal Flemming and some of whom have not. I am still meeting with members of the Council at their request. I make no apology for that.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security a question about the views expressed in the annual report of the Director of Public Prosecutions about welfare fraud and the belief expressed there that the Department of Social Security and the Australian Federal Police are capable of uncovering only minor cases and very serious cases. Is it true that these two bodies are unable to investigate properly a large group of fraud cases which fall between these two extremes? Are the briefs prepared by DSS field officers of poor quality and therefore of little use to either the AFP or the DPP? Does the Minister agree with the views expressed by the Director of Public Prosecutions and is it true that many cases of welfare fraud go undetected?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has my colleague the Minister for Social Security, I have seen the report of the Director of Public Prosecutions. We note that over 1,900 prosecutions were conducted last year by the Director of Public Prosecutions under the Social Security Act. These prosecutions were all based on inquiries and work done by the Department of Social Security and its officers. The Director of Public Prosecutions knows that departmental manuals require all cases involving suspected misrepresentation to be investigated. Those cases that are simple, uncomplicated and unlikely to lead to prosecution are handled by the Department of Social Security. Others are referred to the Australian Federal Police. Special guidelines have been issued to the Department of Social Security and the regional commanders of the Federal Police to ensure that procedures are properly conducted.

ANSWER.PARA: The Director of Public Prosecutions mentioned that some briefs are inadequate. The Minister for Social Security obviously is concerned. He is very happy to receive the assistance of the Director of Public Prosecutions to improve briefs if there are problems, although apparently in more than 1,900 cases there were no problems. The Minister would have been happier to receive such a request directly from the Director of Public Prosecutions rather than through the usual method of communication of the Director of Public Prosecution, which seems to be the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is the report to Parliament.

—I was talking about the time before the report to Parliament. Over the last three years the Government has been concerned about social security fraud, as is every government. We have increased the number of members of the Australian Federal Police to enable them to handle this matter better. We have introduced a tightening up of the procedures in the Department of Social Security. For example, we have required those people seeking unemployment benefit to register with the Commonwealth Employment Service-something, I noticed yesterday, that was advocated by the shadow Minister for Social Security some weeks after it had been instituted by the Government. We also want to take up another method of reducing social security fraud which was advocated by the shadow Minister for Social Security so vigorously for the last couple of years; that is, the introduction of an Australia Card. Unfortunately, since then the shadow Minister for Social Security, who has so vigorously advocated such a reform for the last two years, and his predecessor, who has been advocating it since 1981, have been told to belt up by the Leader of the Opposition and told not to express such views any more. They have now suddenly become born again opponents of the Australia Card.
—What about the recommendations of Costigan?

—Dear oh dear! We ought to talk about some of the recommendations of royal commissions in this area. My predecessor, Senator Chaney, quite justifiably handed over practically a whole section of the Department of Social Security to detect social security fraud which was allegedly detected by the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. After a year that investigation by the Department had to be called off because it had found fraud to the extent of $1,200. I may be wrong; it may have been $1,500.

ANSWER.PARA: The simple fact of the matter is that on anybody's estimate-on our side of the Parliament or on the other side-of the amount of money which is ripped off the taxpayer by taxation fraud exceeds every estimate of social security fraud by many times. Yet Opposition members and now the Director of Public Prosecutions put all the emphasis on social security fraud. We take it seriously. We believe anybody caught defrauding the taxpayer through the social security system should be prosecuted. We are showing that we are serious about it by introducing an Australia Card. It is Opposition members who are going to vote against it to protect the tax evaders; they are not worried about social security fraud.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the anti-conservation media campaign presently being conducted by the Forest Industries Campaign Association Ltd, FICA. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: INDONESIA: FAILURE TO RENEW JOURNALIST'S VISA

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the recent decision of the Indonesian Government not to renew a visa for the Australian Financial Review correspondent in Jakarta, Michael Byrnes. Has the Government sought or received from the Indonesian Government an explanation for the decision? Did the Government assist in any way the attempts of the Australian Financial Review to have the visa renewed? If not, will it consider doing so?

—The Government regrets the Indonesian Government's decision not to renew Mr Byrnes's visa past its expiry date of 23 November. Over recent months the Government has taken up with the Indonesians the question of the renewal of Mr Byrnes's visa. We are disappointed that this decision will now leave no Australian correspondents resident in Indonesia. More generally, the Government is disappointed at the decision of the Indonesian Government to deny entry visas to Australian journalists. The Government has indicated to the Indonesian Government on a number of occasions its support for the free flow of information between Australia and Indonesia. Access to Indonesia by Australian journalists is obviously integral to this end. Most recently, the Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, made this point to the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Dr Mochtar, during the Association of South East Nations post-ministerial conference discussions in Manila in June. The Government's support for the principle of Press freedom is unequivocal and is well known internationally.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security whether his attention has been drawn to a recent article in the Australian in which Katharine West advocated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the dole should be phased out within a year . . . the minimum time required to organise socially or economically productive opportunities for that proportion of dole recipients who are now genuinely unable to obtain work or training.
Is this a realistic proposition? What would be the social effect of such action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must admit that I no longer read Ms West's articles in the Australian because they are basically the same article. I am much more concerned about the fate of Dick Davenport in Garry Trudeau's cartoon Doonesbury. I find it far closer to reality than anything Ms West writes. I did hear someone mention that she has given up the family. Apparently she is not mentioning the family in every article because she has had so many herself. She is now recommending that the dole should be phased out within a year, I gather. She says that this would enable us to organise economically and socially productive activities for those 600,000-odd people who are unemployed in this country at the moment.

ANSWER.PARA: Miss West-or Ms West, or whatever she goes by now-has a real problem. On the one hand she advocates that we must drastically reduce government expenditure, that we must practically wipe out the Public Service in this country. On the other hand, the next week she states that we should treble or quadruple family allowances and double dependent spouse rebates. A week later still, in another variation-this is a new variation-she says that we should employ an army of public servants to get everybody who is on the dole into employment. She says that we should provide another army to provide some special jobs for them which are what she calls `socially and economically productive'. She is advocating the biggest public intervention in the economy that anyone could possibly conceive. At the same time she is advocating an enormous cut in government expenditure and an enormous cut in the Public Service. That is not economics; that is witchcraft. `Black magic', I suppose, would be a less sexist term to use about Ms West. That is black magic. That is nonsense, as is most of the stuff she writes. I advise everybody that the terrible death of Dick Davenport and the fate of Lacey Davenport in her election campaign, in Garry Trudeau's cartoon, are much better and a more practical guide to what is happening in this community. We will find more answers there than we will ever find in the nonsense written by Ms West.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and it follows his answer yesterday on the identity card and the cash economy. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that the identity card system cannot assist in detecting cash economy transactions when there is no requirement for the issue of group certificates, tax stamp sheets and so on and where there is no documentary record of the cash transaction? Do the cash transactions not caught by the ID card system include all household transactions under $10,000, including the employment of gardeners, painters, plumbers, electricians and other household handymen?

—There are a lot of questions there about details of specific applications of the ID card, the answers to which, quite frankly, I do not know. However, I do know that the information circulated by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia last Sunday, I think it was, is absolutely false. The Deputy Leader of the National Party asserted that for every livestock sale or transaction the Australia Card would have to be produced. That, of course, is absolutely false and typical of the misinformation and disinformation which the Opposition delights in circulating about almost all government policies. On the question of livestock sales it is, of course, very necessary that the identity of the seller be correctly recorded, as it is necessary--

—I rise on a point of order. I asked the Minister a fairly straightforward and, indeed, fairly simple question about the Australia Card and its application to cash transactions. The Minister claimed total ignorance but is now proceeding to try to give us a detailed answer on a question that was not raised. He is showing his usual capacity to address what he alleges to be the Opposition's position and his apparent incapacity to address the Government's position. Mr President, I ask you to direct his attention to the question that was asked and seek him to reply in a relevant manner instead of debating the question by raising issues which have nothing to do with the question asked.

—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister was asked a question on the ID card and I understand that he is embracing that subject in a way. He is not debating the matter as yet and I declare that he is in order, but I draw his attention to standing order 100 nonetheless.
—I will not go into the livestock question any more because there will probably be another question about that later when I will give the Opposition the whole bucket.
—But you will not debate it, will you?

—No, I certainly will not debate it. The substantial relevance or importance of the Australia Card-the elimination of tax evasion in those areas where the payer is claiming a payment as a deduction from the payer's taxable income-I think was dealt with yesterday sufficiently comprehensively for even the Opposition to understand if it wanted to. There are, of course-I think this is what Senator Chaney is getting at-other transactions where the payer cannot claim as a deduction from the payer's taxable income the amount paid for a service rendered. Under those circumstances, the discipline on the payer to report the payment with the proper Australia Card number which identifies with certainty the recipient of the payment is very much weaker or indeed is quite weak. However, the Australia Card will still have, in an indirect way, a very substantial effect on the level of tax evasion within that cash economy for household services, the payment for which is not deductible from taxable income. For example, if a person is in the habit of receiving his income in that way-that is, not declaring it or alternatively declaring portions of the income received, perhaps under a variety of different names in order to reduce the average tax rate which is payable, possibly to reduce it down to zero-what can he then do with the money? The acquisition of the money has not been legitimately recorded. If the Australia Card were operating, on an attempt to dispose of the money the disposal would be cross-checked in a variety of ways. For example, if somebody had earned a lot of money which had not been declared as taxable income-I have no doubt that plenty of honourable senators would know about this-unless he wants to stick it in a mattress, when in effect it becomes an interest free loan to the Government, I suppose, or burns it, what does he do with it? Does he buy a house? With the Australia Card system operating he would get caught for tax evasion if he bought a house, as he would if he put the money into a bank account, as he would if he tried to remit it overseas, as he would if he tried to buy shares in a company. In other words, he would hardly be able to enjoy the fruits of his ill-gotten gains--
—Order! We are now getting into the realm of debate and I ask the Minister to come back to the question.
—It is true that the Australia Card will be less effective in those areas where the payment is not tax deductible. However, it would still have a significant influence on closing down such loopholes.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for confirming that household transactions of the sort I identified with gardeners, painters, plumbers, electricians and so on will not be caught by the card in any direct sense. With respect to the Minister's question about what to do with the money, I ask: Will the Australia Card have to be produced to bookmakers and other gambling outlets, which are traditional outlets for the laundering of cash money, and will it have to be produced every time one uses cash to purchase goods in a store, which is another way tax free money can be used?

—I did not confirm that what Senator Chaney said was correct. I do not believe that the Australia Card will be required to be produced to bookmakers. For crooks, that has been a long-standing excuse for explaining away money they cannot account for in any other way. I recall that in New South Wales in the last century a corrupt Lands Minister called Willis tried to explain away his ill-gotten gains in that way. However, that plea does not always work, something that was well known to Mr Willis, who promptly hopped on a boat in Sydney and took off to South Africa and never came back. The excuse that a person won the money at the races is one that a lot of people have tried, of course. It does not always work.

—The Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry and the Treasurer is apparently aware of a report in the Sun-Herald on 16 November that National Party Deputy Leader Ralph Hunt had sent 50 copies of the Australia Card Bill to the National Farmers Federation warning it that the Australia Card would have to be produced at cattle sales for every transaction. Does the Australia Card legislation require production of the card at livestock sales? Has tax evasion been a feature of livestock sales in the past?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will be required for livestock sales, assuming they are being conducted through an agent, is that the agent when first doing business with a client will require the production of the card. He will record the card number of the client and ultimately remit that information to the Australian Taxation Office. For subsequent transactions with that agent the production of the card will not be required because the agent has already satisfied the obligation to ensure that the person who is selling the livestock is who he claims to be. It is very necessary to ensure that the sellers of livestock sell the livestock in the correct name and that the transactions are reported.

ANSWER.PARA: I remember that some years ago in the central wheat belt of Western Australia, the area from which I come, pig sales were conducted regularly-fortnightly I think-at a town called Merredin. Every time there was a pig sale the banks, which were located in an adjoining town, used to give Elder Smith a gladstone bag full of crinkly bank notes that would then be taken up to Merredin to the pig sale and handed over to the farmers who sold pigs in names such as Ned Kelly, Bob Menzies and so on. Elder Smith was doing that even before John Elliott took it over. The stock agents, of course, were clearly collaborating in a major tax evasion exercise which flourished for years. The reason it flourished was that the identity of the seller was not accurately recorded on the sale transaction or reported to the Taxation Office. With the Australia Card that sort of taxation fraud will become impossible. Indeed, I think it was virtually wiped out in the Merredin area some time ago. I do not know whether we should assume from Mr Hunt's recent complaint about the tightening up and proper identification of the sellers of livestock that it still flourishes in Mr Hunt's electorate. If it does, perhaps that explains why he is complaining about the introduction of the Australia Card.

The example which I have just given-I know it was a pretty spectacular one because it flourished for years-of gladstone bags stuffed full of bank notes that were taken up from Kellerberrin to Merredin every second week by the stock agents drives home very clearly the point of how essential it is that the seller of goods be properly identified and that the Taxation Office be aware of the transaction. That is something that the Australia Card will ensure occurs.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask the honourable gentleman whether he agrees with the very excellent statement made by Senator Walsh, as reported on the Carleton-Walsh Report a couple of months ago, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I know some people believe . . . that Budget deficits don't matter . . . They do matter in the degree to which they lock in future expenditure. If we had a public debt interest payment, the same level of outlays as it was in 1982-
I interpose, the Fraser years-

we would in this financial year have about $4 billion extra to either cut taxes, increase welfare spending or whatever else you wanted to do with it. But because we have run a sequence of high Budget deficits, we are lumbered with a crippling public debt interest payment which restricts the ability of this Government and governments for the foreseeable future, to deliver the programs they would like to--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator will come to her question.
—Well, I am, Mr President.
—The honourable senator is giving a lot of information.
—I repeat:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . to deliver the programs they would like to deliver.

I have asked the Minister whether he agrees with that statement. I also ask: Will the Minister push in Caucus and Cabinet for a reappraisal of the levels of government expenditure and a mini-Budget to reduce the current disastrous high level of expenditure that the Hawke Government is pursuing, thereby placing the future of Australia in serious jeopardy?

TALK.START.PARA: —If I decide to put anything to Cabinet or Caucus and if I am successful, the honourable senator will hear about it at the appropriate time. But she will not hear about it today at Question Time. I remind Senator Walters of the context in which I believe those remarks of my colleague Senator Walsh were made. They were simply that this Government inherited a prospective $10 billion domestic deficit and--
—That is not true.
—Order! Senator Walters, I have called you to order on a number of occasions at Question Time today. I ask you to desist.

—It has been said by a finer mind than Senator Walters's-if I may say this without being offensive-that the human mind cannot bear too much reality. Senator Walters cannot bear any. The fact is that this Government inherited a prospective $10 billion deficit and the domestic deficit is now $3.5 billion. This Government has brought about that change. If Senator Walters finds that unpalatable, I am sorry.

—What evidence has the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs got that the sinking of the Southern Raider on 9 October and the detention of four Australian and four New Zealand crew members is nothing to do with illegal fishing for lobsters or drug smuggling but is due to French fears of spying? Is it true that the French Government is preparing a nuclear test site on Kerguelen Island, which is about 3,000 kilometres south-west of Perth and from where the prevailing winds blow directly to Australia? Has the Australian Government made any representation to the French Government objecting to the construction of a nuclear test site at Kerguelen, which is close to the Australian islands of Heard and Macdonald and much closer to Australia than Mururoa Atoll? Is the Government prepared to challenge the French authorities to tell the truth about the sinking of the Southern Raider and why the crew has been detained on Reunion Island so that we do not get a repetition of the lies and falsehoods which followed the sinking of the Rainbow Warrior in July 1985?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The captain and second-in-command of the Southern Raider were charged on 17 October with infringing French fishing and merchant navy laws. Subsequently they were placed under judicial control for infringement of drug laws. Magistrates on Reunion are collecting information on the sinking of the Southern Raider to determine whether to proceed to trial. We therefore have no evidence at this stage that the detention of the crew of the Southern Raider is related to French fears of spying. It will not be until the magistrates decide whether to proceed to trial-we have a full list of the formal charges against the crew-that we will be able to determine whether representations to the French Government are appropriate. We have asked the French authorities to finalise the legal processes as quickly as possible so that we can be in a position to respond appropriately.

ANSWER.PARA: The question of possible French interest in nuclear testing on Kerguelen Island first arose in December 1984 when the French Consul-General in Melbourne, speaking in his personal capacity it seems, mooted this possibility. The French Defence Minister at the time, Charles Hernu, denied any such plans and the Australian Government has no reason to doubt this denial. This remains the case today. The Government is not aware of any evidence that would lend support to more speculation about French interest in nuclear testing on Kerguelen. I should just finally add that Australia's strong opposition to French nuclear testing in particular stems from the fact that France is the only country that does conduct nuclear tests outside the home territory of a nuclear weapons state and we have repeatedly insisted that, at the very least, France should take its nuclear test program home to metropolitan France.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the fringe benefits tax payable by non-profit making organisations where non-wage benefits are granted for services rendered by people who are not employees? By way of illustration I refer in particular to an honorary president of a trade union who is not an employee of that union but who receives from it a monthly expense allowance of $450 tax free, totalling $5,400 a year tax free; an honorarium of $200 per working day when not engaged in other official capacities, probably totalling a minimum of $30,000 a year; and free use of a Holden Statesman car. If fringe benefits tax is not payable by the union involved, why not? Are any of those benefits subject to income tax in the recipient's hands, particularly the honorarium payable by the union, the Federated Liquor and Allied Industries Employees Union of Australia, on those days when the Senate is not sitting, to Senator Morris?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fundamental liability for fringe benefits tax is incurred if an employer-employee relationship exists. In the first hypothetical case that was cited, it would rest ultimately, I would expect, on whether the Commissioner of Taxation declared that the person concerned was an employee. If so, the fringe benefits tax would be payable. The fact that either an employer or an employee does not call himself either an employer or an employee I would not expect necessarily means that the Taxation Commissioner will accept his definition. I will refer that to the Treasurer for a more direct answer.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Baume also asked whether honorariums were taxable under the income tax law. My understanding of the matter is that they are not, but I will have that confirmed.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not? You are misleading the Senate again. You are completely wrong.

—I am talking here about a union I do know something about. I do not really know anything about the liquor trades union but I do remember the farmers union in Western Australia, of which I was a member, and I am still a member of the successor organisation. Most years at the State conference the question of the president's honorarium, as I think it used to be called, which was taxable, and allowance, which was not taxable, used to be raised. Year after year it was said: `We can't increase the former because that is taxable, so we will increase the latter'. That, of course, was exactly what was happening on an ever-increasing scale. People who were being paid what was a return for effort-a wage equivalent-were increasingly having that amount converted to a payment that was called something else, frequently, of course, in kind. That is exactly what the farmers union in Western Australia was doing in those days. It was arranging the remuneration of its president in such a way that the level of taxation was minimised. To go back, the term `honorarium' which Senator Michael Baume used was, I think, the term used in the case I have cited. It was the honorarium paid to the president at that time which was taxable. I will have that checked as well with the Treasurer.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I want to know whether the first part of the Minister's answer about honorariums is the one we should take into account, when he said, in fact, that they were not taxable, or the second part of his response, when he said that they were taxable. I am afraid that I cannot understand which of those comments he wants me to believe.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On reflection--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said this before, you silly little woman over there. You are almost as silly as your man.
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.

—Very well, I withdraw, Mr President. I believe that I initially confused the term `honorarium' and `allowance', but at all times I said that it was subject to confirmation. On reflection, I believe what is called an honorarium would be taxable and what is called an allowance would not. I will have that checked.

—Has the Minister representing the Attorney-General seen a report by the Human Rights Commission which includes evidence that prisoners in Australia have virtually no human rights, as claimed by Professor Hawkins of the Sydney University criminology department? Is it true that in New South Wales and Queensland prison regulations do not even acknowledge a prisoner's right to medical treatment? When will the Federal Government take steps to ensure that all Australian prisons comply with the United Nations standard minimum rules for the treatment of prisoners?

—The report to which Senator Reynolds refers is a reported account of a recent paper by Professor Gordon Hawkins, who is not a human rights commissioner. He is not a member of the Commission, as he was described in the Press report, but rather an expert in criminology who is a consultant to the Human Rights Commission and has been carrying out a study on prisoners' rights. Professor Hawkins has prepared an occasional paper, or a discussion paper, entitled `Prisoners' Rights: A study of Human Rights and Commonwealth Prisoners' which, I am advised, is due to be released by the Commission today. I have asked for the paper to be provided to the honourable senator and anyone else who may be interested in it. The occasional paper states that, although the prison regulations of all States, including those of New South Wales and Queensland, have provisions regarding the health care of prisoners and the provision of medical attention, none of them confer any right to medical treatment. A number of other points, apparently, are made in the paper which perhaps justify the kind of language which was reported and which Senator Reynolds refers to. As the paper, however, is not a formal report but is simply issued for the purpose of stimulating discussion it is premature to talk of government action to implement any particular proposals. No doubt that is something the Government will have in mind at the end of the day when this process is complete.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Science aware of extensive research undertaken by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in developing an artificial sweetener called aspartame? Does the Minister agree that this artificial sweetener will be in direct competition with Australia's sugar industry and that CSIRO resources are being used to bolster a product which is in direct competition with one of Australia's most profitable export industries? Why is CSIRO undertaking research in this area when there is already considerable private research being done by large multinational companies in developing artificial sweeteners? Does the Minister agree that CSIRO's scarce resources would be better utilised in further research for and development of our successful and competitive primary industries than in assisting an industry which will be in competition with our rural export industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of one thing relating to the Queensland sugar industry and Senator Bjelke-Petersen ought to be aware of it, too: When this Government came to power in 1983, the Fraser Government was under pressure from the Western Australian Government to support the development of a sugar industry on the Ord River. This Government stopped that in the interests of the Queensland sugar industry. That should not be forgotten by Queensland's sugar farmers. If I might just take Senator Bjelke-Petersen through her question in the course of my answer, let me say at the outset that while I have long recognised her as a protagonist of the flat tax I did not, until she asked this question, have evidence that she was a protagonist of flat earth policies as well. What this question really implies is that the process of scientific investigation and discovery should be limited by the facts which happen to exist in north Queensland; for example, the sugar industry. The process of scientific investigation and discovery cannot be limited by matters like that.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me go through some of the assumptions in the honourable senator's question. I make it quite clear that the sugar industry is already in competition with artificial sweeteners. It will be in competition with artificial sweeteners in the future. Like any other industry it will have to take its chance in the market-place and be the preferred choice of the vast majority of human beings or it will not survive under any circumstance. The research CSIRO is doing in connection with artificial sweeteners has nothing to do with that. I am personally not aware of CSIRO's research into a sweetener called aspartame, I think one calls it. I am delighted to hear that CSIRO is doing research into such a nice sounding product as aspartame. It sounds like an exotic disease to me. Be that as it may, CSIRO performs a great variety of research functions in various industries and for various food products. It will continue to do so. It cannot be deterred by the suggestion that the results of this research might make a marginal impact on Australia's sugar industry. The assumptions in the honourable senator's question are that everybody in the whole world should stop thinking about fabrics other than wool. Because we have a wool industry the honourable senator's assumption is that no research should be commissioned by governments or anybody else into man made fibres.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the private enterprise people research it.

—I understand Senator Boswell's interjections. From him they are totally understandable but not from anybody who has given the issues any serious thought. Research into a whole range of products of this kind will go on. Some of that research has led to great success in new primary industries in Australia.
—It is a chemical product.

—There is a product which is marketed under the name betatene which is an artificial ingredient used in margarine. I know that the honourable senator is against margarine but let us assume that we have margarine. A product has been developed by research in Australia which adds colour and certain other properties including, I believe, vitamin properties to margarine. That is partly a result of research by Commonwealth-funded bodies. That is a highly successful export industry.
—That might have been worth while.

—Senator Lewis says: `That might have been worth while'. Of course it might have been worth while. It is worth while. One of the great disabilities from which all human beings suffer and from which members of the Opposition in the Senate suffer more than others is the incapacity to decide the precise direction of all scientific endeavour. That is a great disability. I am sorry that we cannot all decide such questions. On the basis of this question, as by implication I am invited to, I do not propose to make any interference in CSIRO's research programs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the Senate how many South Pacific Forum countries have signed the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty? When will the protocols to the Treaty be open for signature? Have any indications been given by the eligible states as to whether they will adhere to the protocols?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To date 10 of the 13 South Pacific Forum countries have signed the Treaty of Rarotonga-the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty-and seven have now deposited instruments of ratification. Eight ratifications are required for the Treaty to enter into force. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill to clear the way for Australia's ratification is before Parliament. I hope that it will be able to be debated in the Senate early next week. The protocols to the Treaty which will be open for signature on 1 December provide for the United States, the United Kingdom and France to apply the provisions of the Treaty to their South Pacific territories and for the nuclear weapons states-the United States, the United Kingdom, France, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and China-to undertake not to use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against parties to the Treaty nor to conduct nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the Government's very strong hope that all the eligible states which have major responsibility for international peace and security will adhere to the protocols. The situation with respect to each of these parties at the moment is as follows: The United States is studying the protocols with an open mind. It would appear that some sections of the United States Administration have a more open mind than others in that respect. France has declared publicly that it will not sign. Although we hope that that is not its final position, at the moment it appears that it may be. We are reiterating the point that the Treaty manifestly is not anti-French, as has been alleged, but pro-South Pacific in character. The United Kingdom, like the United States, is still considering the matter. The Soviet Union has said that it will sign and China has also indicated a positive attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a resolution from the Australian War Memorial Council which includes the signatures of members of the Council present at the meeting last evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I do not wish to debate the matter at this stage. The paper relates to the matter which was the subject of a resolution in the Senate yesterday and a series of questions today and yesterday. I note that the Australian War Memorial Council resolves:
. . . that . . . in all circumstances, that it no longer has the confidence that Air Vice-Marshal Flemming can properly manage the affairs of the Australian War Memorial in accordance with the Act.

I take this occasion to say that I think that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has got himself, the Memorial and Mr Flemming into a situation which is quite intolerable. I simply repeat today the request which the Senate made of him, that this matter be dealt with in a more satisfactory way than the Minister has dealt with it to the present. There has been an inquiry in which it is common ground between the War Memorial and Air Vice-Marshal Flemming that the rules of natural justice have not been satisfied. There are contested issues of fact and yet on the findings of that inquiry into the Australian War Memorial by Mr Jones, Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is not guilty of misconduct of a sort which entitles him to be dismissed, a view which the Minister publicly disputes. It is the Opposition's view that we are left in a situation which may not be capable of resolution and which certainly will not be resolved to anybody's final satisfaction if the Minister's present course is stuck with.

If the Minister and the Council pursue a course which is to amend the law to make the dismissal of Air Vice-Marshal Flemming possible without Air Vice-Marshal Flemming having any right to contest the contested issues of fact, an important section of the community will continue to distrust the whole administration of the War Memorial, something that I believe the Minister would not wish. I repeat to the Minister the request which was made to him by the Opposition at Question Time, that he should either have a full legal inquiry of the sort which Air Vice-Marshal Flemming has requested, in which these contested issues of fact can be dealt with satisfactorily and once and for all, or, if the Minister and the Council are going to persist with their course of seeking to dismiss Air Vice-Marshal Flemming notwithstanding the finding of Mr Jones that he is not guilty of misconduct, leave the law in the situation in which Air Vice-Marshal Flemming will have access to some tribunal where these disputed questions of fact can be determined. It seems to me that if the Minister gets his way Air Vice-Marshal Flemming will be left without a remedy and there will be no way of the contesting views of this matter being finally settled. I believe to have that hanging over the institution of the War Memorial would be a serious error of judgment on the part of the Minister, on the part of the Government, and on the part of the Council.

I make this additional entry into the debate now because I believe that there will be widespread disquiet in the community if that state of affairs is allowed to continue. I believe that the Minister, on sober reflection, will agree that it would be a most unfortunate end to this matter. I am unable to predict what stance the Opposition would take if such legislation were introduced into this place. But I put the Minister on notice that we certainly will be concerned if these contested issues of fact are not determined and a cloud is left hanging over a very important national institution. Too many allegations and questions have been raised for the matter to be swept under the carpet in the way that I think is envisaged under the present proposal. I put the Minister on notice that we will not be prepared to put this matter down if natural justice is not observed and if Air Vice-Marshal Flemming is not treated fairly.

The Opposition does not make a judgment on whether Air Vice-Marshal Flemming should or should not continue as the Director of the Australian War Memorial. That is a matter on which we do not have the advice of a finding on those contested issues of fact. That is a matter which we cannot determine because we have the Air Vice-Marshal's views, we have other views, and those views have never been tested. We will certainly not be satisfied with a situation in which the matter is left up in the air in this way. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I think there would be common ground that nobody in the Parliament, either in the House of Representatives or in the Senate, would want in any way to be involved in actions which would disturb or destroy the important place the Australian War Memorial has in the hearts and minds not only of veterans but also of other citizens throughout Australia. It is a very important institution and one that we cherish greatly for its very innovative and commemorative work. However, having said that, it is also the responsibility of the Government-and, in my case, of the Minister-to ensure that the War Memorial functions in accordance with the Act. To that extent, there have been numerous inquiries which have all found serious problems of maladministration. I do not want to go too far down that track. I ask the Opposition: In what way is it relying upon a statement that Air Vice-Marshal Flemming has been denied natural justice?

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Chaney was heard in silence. I ask that the same consideration be given to the Minister.

—The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney)-I respect his view and his position-has raised the question of denial of natural justice. I see no evidence of this. Until the Opposition can present such evidence, other than the say-so of the Director himself, all the advice that is available to me, and certainly all the evidence I have, is that in respect of the matters I raised with the investigation and its agent, Mr Jones, there was no question that it required witnesses to canvass correspondence and communications between the Director and me.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand the issue, the Council did give both Mr Jones and Air Vice-Marshal Flemming every opportunity to explain their views and conclusions on the evidence that was collected. I think that one of the great misnomers in the current difficulties is the repetitive suggestion that there has been a denial of natural justice. I urge the Opposition to test that with members of the Council to see whether they failed in their responsibilities to inquire, in an acceptable form, and consistent with natural justice, in regard to Mr Jones's report and the Council's response thereto. The only advice I can give is what is told to me. In those circumstances I am satisfied that there has been no denial of natural justice.

I am certainly satisfied in respect of the issues I raised-the six issues involving public accountability-and in respect of my responsibilities to this Parliament to avoid giving misleading information, that the files of the Memorial, my Department and my office speak for themselves insofar as a whole range of issues in dispute. It is not a question of whether I or Air Vice-Marshal Flemming would be cross-examined on those substantive issues. DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the revised explanatory memorandum for the Bill and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes a number of amendments to the Customs and Excise Acts. The principal amendments are at clauses 7 and 13 of the Bill.

Clause 7 which was inserted into the Bill during the Committee stages in the other place proposes to close a possible gap in the law by making it clear that it is an offence to bring narcotics into Australia either as a transit passenger or otherwise.

Clause 13 proposes to give effect to the Government's decision to introduce revised excise duty rebate arrangements on exports and domestic free market sales of Bass Strait crude oil. These arrangements are being introduced to allow more timely settlement of rebate claims, and thus increase the attractiveness of free market sales to the Bass Strait producers.
The Bill contains a number of other amendments of a technical or administrative nature and I will provide brief details of the more important of these in a few moments.

The new narcotics offence at clause 7 flows from legal advice indicating doubt as to the adequacy of existing law to ensure successful prosecution of persons who bring drugs into Australia when they are not intended for Australian consumption.

As a result of the uncertain state of the law the Government acknowledges that there has been one instance where a person has not been prosecuted. That case involved a person in transit through Australia who allegedly was taking narcotics from India to Canada.
We intend however that in future such persons will be amenable to the full force of the law.

It is our view that it is quite wrong and indeed contrary to our drug strategy for in transit traffickers or couriers to avoid prosecution when the drugs they are carrying are not intended to be unloaded in Australia.

This Government is committed to a positive attack against dealers in this shameful trade, dealers in the ultimate in human misery and degradation and we consider it most undesirable that legal controversy should arise over any law designed to fight the drug menace in Australia.

Consistent with other similar offence provisions in the customs Act involving drugs the proposed offence exempts from liability persons who have a reasonable excuse for their conduct. As with other drug offences in the Customs Act the persons seeking to escape liability on the basis of an excuse must establish that excuse on the balance of probabilities. We make no apology for this just as we make no apology for the severity of any other offence involving drugs.
The Government issues a firm warning that no person will in future be immune from prosecution in Australia if he or she engages in the distasteful trade in illicit narcotics.

The provisions of clause 13 of the Bill form part of the Government's initiatives announced in July this year to stimulate domestic production and encourage exports of crude oil produced from Bass Strait.

Since the beginning of 1986 the unsettled international oil market has had a significant and adverse impact on the Australian oil and energy industries. With the downward trend in world oil prices, Bass Strait crude oil production and Australian crude oil exports sourced from these production areas has dropped dramatically. The Government, concerned with the revenue and balance of payments effects of reduced oil production reflected in low domestic free market sales and the gradual cessation of export shipments, announced in July a package of measures to stimulate domestic production and encourage crude oil exports.

One of the measures introduced on 1 July 1986, was to reduce the effective top rate of crude oil excise on free market sales of `old' oil by a sliding scale ranging from 65 per cent at $12.50 or less per barrel to 87 per cent at $35.00 or more per barrel.

By the end of July however, Australian crude oil prices had fallen to their lowest level since 1979 and this naturally had serious ramifications for the cash flow and financial viability of the Australian oil industry.

In order to further encourage the resumption of free market sales the Government also decided that from 1 August 1986 the top marginal excise duty rate for `old' oil would be reduced from 87 per cent to 80 per cent subject to certain review provisions.
I should mention that excise duty rebates have been paid on exports of crude oil since 1984. These rebates have been implemented by excise regulations made approximately every 6 months.
To provide the necessary market stimulus it is now necessary to introduce a mechanism for the payment of the export rebates and rebates on domestic free market sales on a monthly basis.

The Government believes that the most suitable and expedient method to achieve this is to have the Minister for Resources and Energy determine by notification in the Gazette the rebates of excise duty payable on exports and domestic free market sales of Bass Strait crude oil. This should ensure that a monthly settlement of excise duty rebates can be accommodated, thereby increasing the attractiveness of these sales and exports to the Bass Strait producers.

The provisions of clause 13 of this Bill provide that similar to regulations the proposed Gazette notices are to be subject to tabling and disallowance by the parliament in the usual way. This mechanism is proposed in order to preserve the parliament's important scrutiny over this administrative tool.

As evidence of the timeliness and efficacy of the Government's policy initiatives aimed at increasing production and crude oil exports, there were only ten export shipments in the first half of 1986 and Bass Strait productions averaged only 320,000 barrels a day in the second quarter of 1986. By contrast, since 1 August 1986 nineteen export sales have been completed, valued at about $240 million. More significantly, however, is that Bass Strait production levels are currently running at 480,000 barrels per day and the Bass Strait producers are confident of achieving export sales averaging 70,000 barrels per day in the current financial year.
I now turn to the important amendments of a technical or administrative nature contained in the Bill.

Clauses 5 and 16 effect minor amendments to the provisions in the customs and excise Acts respectively, relating to the obligations on ship and aircraft owners to provide information relating to ship's or aircraft's stores, including drugs, which are on board on arrival in Australia, or are taken on board while in Australia. The proposed amendments update the administrative requirements for the provisions of this type of information, to facilitate and accommodate the use of modern media to transmit this data.

Clause 6 effects a technical amendment to section 151 of the Customs Act, to transfer from the Minister to the Comptroller-General of Customs the power to treat goods as the manufacture of a forum island country, for the purposes of determining duty under the Customs Tariff Act. This transfer of power is consistent with the general transfer of administrative functions from the Minister to the Comptroller-General in Customs Legislation, as implemented by the two Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Acts of 1985 and 1986. The transfer of powers vested the day to day administration of the Customs in the Comptroller-General, and the proposed amendment in clause 6 continues that theme.

Other amendments at clauses 11 and 12 are linked to the Government's crude oil and LPG policy. These clauses which were also inserted during the committee stages in the other place are closely related to the proposals at clause 13.

Government policy provides that all crude oil production in Australia is subject to excise duty. When production, upon which excise duty is paid, is exported a rebate is payable which amounts to a part of the excise duty paid on production. This policy has been publicised on a number of occasions since exports of crude oil commenced in 1983.

Before excise duty can be collected it is necessary that the oil be entered for home consumption. Recent legal advice indicates that current legislation might not support the Government's policy of collecting excise on all crude oil production when some production is exported. The provisions of clauses 11 and 12 clarify the position by requiring that exports must first be entered for home consumption.

The provisions of those clauses will not have the effect of introducing a further step in the process or imposing additional regulation upon the industry. They merely deem that production is entered for home consumption on the day it is delivered for exportation and do no more than provide legislative backing for existing practice by both the producers and the Australian Customs Service. There is no increase in excise liability or administration for the producers.

The fast track rebate mechanism as proposed by clause 13 in the Bill seeks to encourage exports by speeding up the payment of rebates to the producers. Clauses 11 and 12 will not effect that fast track mechanism.

Provision has been made for the amendments in clauses 11 and 12 not to apply to crude oil and LPG production from the area known as Jabiru in the Northern Territory. This is for the reason that Jabiru production is proposed to be removed from excise control under the provisions of the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 in accordance with the Government's Resource Rent Tax Policy.
Financial Impact Statement
The provisions of this Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
