DEBATE.TITLE: SCIENCE AND INDUSTRY RESEARCH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Grimes) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the revised explanatory memorandum for the Bill and seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill concerns the future directions of one of Australia's most important resources-and I am not now talking of iron ore, coal, bauxite or uranium, but of the intellectual resources within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, CSIRO.

Just how much depends on CSIRO's performance over the next few years is, I believe, not widely enough understood in the community, because Australians still tend to define resources in purely material terms, and rarely relate it to intellect and human capacity.

This attitude contrasts markedly with attitudes in countries such as Switzerland, Holland, Belgium, Sweden and Israel, to mention countries with populations smaller than our own, where human skills are invariably recognised as being of paramount importance.

Australia has no option but to develop similar attitudes if it is to survive economically for the remainder of this century. Australian business management, in particular, will have to change direction radically, and devote a far greater degree of attention to human skills than it has in the past. This will inevitably mean making use of CSIRO, because CSIRO is the single greatest reservoir of technological skills and knowledge this nation possesses.

In most other Western nations, government-funded research and development is paralleled by a strong private research and development capacity, but the Australian private sector, outside agriculture and mining, has for decades all but ignored the need for research and development, with the result that Government has been left to shoulder the task of fostering scientific talent and expertise.

In examining the future of CSIRO, the Government was conscious that it would be setting the directions and structure for the Organisation for some years to come. Furthermore, CSIRO's role in performing longer-term, strategic research means that it is necessary to consider Australia's future, to ask where we as a nation are headed, when setting the context for decisions on CSIRO's future.

There has been a profound change in perception over the last year or so of Australia's place in the world. In 1984-85 there was a prevailing euphoria about the State of Australia's economy. After all, it was reasoned, if we had the world's strongest economy and the world's highest growth rate, then structural improvements in the economy hardly seemed necessary. Concern about the inadequacy of Australia's scientific and technological base was not popular in 1983 and 1984.

Underlying the Government's decision on future directions for CSIRO was a belief that Australia must develop as a nation that makes much greater use of its intellectual resources. If we are to arrest the relative decline in Australia's standard of living, Australia must become a more intellectually active scientific and technological culture. However, simple adoption of technology from overseas at a greater rate, or more effectively, will not create the required environment in Australia for acceptance and development of new technologies. A strong local capability in research and development, directed to the opportunities of the future, not the past, is essential. This will be the fundamental role of the restructured CSIRO resulting from the Amendment Bill before the House today.
To provide context for the future directions which the Government has identified for CSIRO, I would like to look briefly at our past.

By 1900 Australia was a world leader in technology and its per capita income was the highest in the world, followed by Argentina. Our prosperity was based on our agricultural output and our natural resource endowment. Technological developments spurred by the need to be competitive, were responsible for our pre- eminence in the world economy of the time.

However, we have not used our initial success as a springboard to industrial growth. Instead, we have relied on our efficient agricultural and mining industries while our manufacturing and other industries remained poorly developed.

Agriculture and mining, employing just 7 per cent of our labour force, account for more than 80 per cent of out export earnings, if we include the value of secondary processing. This is not a sign of strength, as the fastest-growing sector in world trade has been in high value-added, brain based goods for about 15 years.

Theoretically, that 80 per cent plus figure could increase to 100 per cent as some farming and mining groups have urged. If it did, this would be a catastrophe, putting us at the mercy of declining world commodity prices, providing a disincentive to restructuring and updating our economic and technological base. Our urban society would be a mere appendage to the rural and mining base.

Australia produces large volumes of raw materials, high bulk, low-added-value goods, at a time when alternative suppliers are coming on stream, and where traditional markets are either becoming self-sufficient or are adopting trade policies which are adverse to us.

In the fastest growing areas of world trade-low bulk, high-value-added, brain based or brand-name goods, we are very small producers, having left our run extremely late. In technology-based goods, of the 24 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations, Australia ranked 23rd in 1984 in the imbalance between the value of imports and exports. Only Iceland had worse figures.

There are serious, long term and-in my view-irreversible problems in agriculture, complicated locally by drought, but also by our national preoccupation with the short term, and failure to grasp long term trends.

The most productive year in the history of world agriculture was 1985, with outputs 12 per cent higher than ever before. A green revolution has swept Asia in the past 15 years. China is now self-sufficient in grain. India now has a grain surplus of 35 million tonnes, locked away in silos. Indonesia, for the first time in many years, is now a grain exporter. Britain, still a major farming nation, has had unusually good harvests.

The minerals situation is similar. The overheated minerals boom, that began in the 1960s and continued through the early 1980s, was based on heroic assumptions of a continuing world-wide growth in demand for base metals we could produce in large volume and with steadily rising prices. These assumptions have not been fulfilled. Other sources of supply-notably Brazil-are now selling at a lower cost, while the technological revolution has brought an era of parsimony in the use of natural resources.

The latest preoccupation of Australian politics and the media-the emergence of the so-called New Right-is a relatively insignificant part of a much greater problem. In passing I must comment that a leading member of the New Right, as late as 1979, was positively advocating a reduction in Australia's manufacturing capability and exports in order that our dollar would not be upvalued too much by the large forecast increase in mineral exports and capital inflow to the minerals industry.

The strategies of most other western nations during the 1950s and 1960s were quite different from our own. The companies of Japan, Europe and the United States of America, attracted by the economic growth prospects of most economies, spread out across the world opening up new markets with new products and processes. This competition spurred heavy research and development investment, innovation, product and overseas market development, yielding handsome returns and an economic resilience which allowed them to survive the economic recession of the 1980s better than most.

The major factor in the rise of resource-poor nations has been the proportion of export earnings directly attributable to intellectual input: invention, research and development, product innovation, design, patents, royalties and copyright. More than 60 per cent of the annual export earnings of Japan, France, Sweden, the Netherlands and Italy depend on `brain-based' industries, while Australia's figure is probably less than 5 per cent. The skill-based earnings of our industrial contemporaries will grow. Ours will contract unless we make a fundamental change in direction.

The most important political issue we face is how to bring Australia up to date, how to come to grips with the social and political significance of the technological revolution that has swept the Western world in the past 25 years.
Australia missed the bus on being an active participant in that revolution, and is now paying the price for its low level of intellectual vitality and for remaining in the mental world of the 1960s.
We still have to learn the lesson that the world does not owe us a living. It is dangerous for us to conclude that all other nations are out of step and they must learn to march with us.
What Australia must do is also what CSIRO must do. CSIRO has made enormous contributions towards the success of our agriculture and minerals industries.

I believe CSIRO's most important role over the coming years will be to work with those industries in which research and development plays a central role. In particular, CSIRO will play a major role in contributing to the Government's program of restructuring and revitalising high-technology manufacturing, and in supporting the emerging information and space technology industries.

The scientific work of CSIRO will, of course, continue to benefit the resource based primary industries, particularly by adding value to products before they leave our shores, and by tailoring them to meet specific overseas market needs.

The present level of private sector industrial research and development in Australia must be increased. This is the most critical factor in achieving a more internationally competitive and skill-based industrial capability in Australia. CSIRO will have an important supportive role in achieving this goal.

Over the past few years, CSIRO has substantially improved its interactions with manufacturing industry. The trend started in 1980, with the establishment of the new Division of Manufacturing Technology. The number of professional staff engaged in manufacturing-oriented research has grown by nearly 100 since 1981, an increase of some 15 per cent. Research in manufacturing now accounts for 27 per cent of professional staff. Growth in the manufacturing effort is a trend I expect to continue, and work for the information industries is also growing rapidly.

CSIRO's international standing as a research establishment is beyond dispute. It is certainly higher than its national standing, at least in some sectors. Ironically, the Bell Laboratories, world leaders in communications technology, have a higher opinion of CSIRO's research capacity than the local competitory AWA.

CSIRO has collaborated with industry in the development of many products which are being exported, or are about to be. These range from the high-speed vision processor, a major advance in the field of robotic vision, to the extremely strong ceramic called `partially stabilised zirconia', which has a wide range of potential applications.
The Government is looking to CSIRO to play a role in assisting industry to a much greater export orientation, as well as to continue support for our more traditional industries.

This is vital to Australia's future prosperity. It is precisely because the Government places great store by CSIRO and has great expectations of it that we are introducing this new legislation aimed at carrying the Organisation into the next decade in the best possible shape.

In May 1985 the Government requested the Australian Science and Technology Council to conduct a total review of public investment in research and development. ASTEC published its report `Future Directions for CSIRO' in November, and the Minister for Science announced in June that the Government had accepted the broad thrust of the ASTEC recommendations.

This legislation is based in part on those recommendations, and provides for CSIRO to be maintained as a single entity, in order to achieve maximum efficiency and flexibility in responding to changing national research priorities.

The Government considers that CSIRO's primary role should continue to be applications-oriented research in support of major industry sectors and selected areas of community interest, with a commitment to the effective transfer of its results to users.

To help CSIRO place more emphasis on the application of its research, the Organisation is being encouraged to take on more short-term problem solving projects, to be paid for largely by the individual companies concerned. An important objective of this is to gain a better knowledge of industries' needs, and to foster mutual respect and confidence. It is not intended that CSIRO substitute for industry performing its own research and development, but rather that it back up and stimulate industry to do more for itself. The major emphasis for CSIRO with its own funds will remain, where it should, on contributing to future industrial development by longer-term `strategic' research.

The Government will give clear guidance to CSIRO about Government policies and priorities. The Minister for Science will issue guidelines to CSIRO from time to time setting out policies and priorities which the Government wishes CSIRO to follow. In addition, CSIRO will continue to prepare three to five year strategic plans, which will be submitted to the Minister, and annual operating plans. The Minister will retain a statutory power of direction.

Changing the top structure will be an important element in building closer links between CSIRO and industry and the community. The legislation clearly separates the top-level policy body-the Board-from management functions. The former Executive will be replaced by a Board having a part-time non-executive Chairman and six to eight part-time members appointed for their personal abilities, not as representatives of sectional interests. The Chief Executive will be the only full-time member of the Board.

The Board will be responsible for setting the broad policy directions within the general policy context established by the Government. The Board members, including the Chief Executive, will be appointed by the Governor-General in Council for a maximum period of five years, but will be eligible for reappointment.
The Chief Executive, who will be the most senior member of the Organisation, will have responsibility for the management of the activities of CSIRO within the directions established by the Board.

The Government has decided that CSIRO should be able to retain its earnings from outside sources without this leading to a decrease in appropriation. Although future levels of funding will continue to be determined in the annual Budget context, this decision should provide a major incentive to CSIRO to strengthen its links with industry, and the application orientation of its research.

Although the Advisory Council and State and Territory Committees have provided valuable advice and direction to the Executive, it is clear that the structure has not been ideal. The Government has therefore decided to repeal that section of the Science and Industry Research Act which establishes these bodies, and to empower the incoming Board to set up non-statutory channels of advice from industry and the community.

Representations from the outlying States of Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania have all expressed concern at this provision, but the special needs of these areas outside the Sydney-Melbourne axis are recognised and I am confident that the proposed non-statutory channels of advice will give appropriate and effective State representation.

The Government is also proposing to establish a House of Representatives Standing Committee on Science and Technology, which I believe will be a major step in improving CSIRO's interaction with and responsiveness to Parliament.

The present CSIRO Consultative Council, which comprises staff and management representatives, will be retained to provide an effective forum for the representation of staff views within the management structure.

The ASTEC report on CSIRO raised a number of other important issues concerning use of resources, conditions of service for research staff, funding and financial arrangements. ASTEC's recommendations on these matters will be subject to consideration, in the first instance, by the incoming board, and subsequently by me in consultation with other Ministers as appropriate.
The Bill also provides that the Chief Executive should administer the Science and Industry Endowment Fund, a fund used to support scientific endeavours which do not have access to mainstream funding.

The changes to CSIRO embodied in the new legislation are complementary to other initiatives introduced by the Government aimed at transforming the research and development climate in Australia. These initiatives include the Grants for Industry Research and Development Scheme, the 150 per cent taxation concession, the National Industry Extension Service and revised offsets arrangements.

The legislation also incorporates and formalises a number of changes that were under way within CSIRO at the time of the ASTEC review, particularly the five-year strategy for development aimed at improving the focus, management and use of the Organisation's research.

I am very optimistic about CSIRO's future. This legislation will give impetus to the positive changes that have already taken place within the Organisation, and will also reflect the Government's desire to enhance CSIRO's responsiveness to community needs. I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to implement a Government decision that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service should be amalgamated from 1 January 1987.

Honourable senators will be aware that the decision to amalgamate the two broadcasting organisations was announced by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech. Accordingly, the Government sees the amalgamation as a Budget-related matter.
Before dealing with the provisions of the Bill, I would wish to make some general points in respect of the objective to be achieved by this legislation.

The decision to amalgamate the two broadcasting organisations was taken in the context of a difficult Budget and the conclusion that this country could no longer continue to afford to support two separately Budget-funded national broadcasting organisations. Nowhere else in the world are there two separate government supported national broadcasters and, indeed, there is widespread recognition of increasing difficulty in meeting the costs of such organisations totally from government budgets. The Government expects that there will be appreciable cost savings in the long term, and has in fact identified the objective of achieving some savings to the Budget in 1986-87.

Having taken the decision to amalgamate the two organisations, the Government will ensure that it is done in a manner which will retain the strengths of the two existing organisations and combine them in a way which will serve to enhance the services provided through the National Broadcasting Service.

In considering the legislation necessary to implement the amalgamation, the Government took advice from a steering committee chaired by the Secretary of the Department of Communications and chief executives of the ABC and SBS. The provisions outlined in the Bill are essentially those which have come to the Government from the steering committee.

One of the threshold questions was whether to establish the amalgamated organisation under a totally new structure under a new Act. In the end result, the Government accepted the recommendation of the steering committee that the objective of an efficient and cost-effective amalgamation would best be achieved by seeking to amend the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act. Accordingly, the Bill seeks to reflect a broader responsibility of the ABC to cover the functions and responsibilities previously undertaken by the Special Broadcasting Service.

I would wish to stress the Government's intention that there should be an amalgamation of the two organisations in the full sense of that word. From 1 January 1987 the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will not only continue its previously established services, but will ensure continuation of a multicultural television service in those cities served by the SBS and an ethnic radio service in both Sydney and Melbourne through stations 2EA and 3EA.

The amendments contained in the Bill will not add to the costs or revenues of the Commonwealth. It is expected that, in the long term, financial savings will accrue from the amalgamation. Such savings should occur in areas relating to rationalisation of accommodation, reduced overheads and economies in areas of program production and acquisition. Budget savings for the 1986-87 financial year have been estimated as $2 million.

The Bill provides for the amendment of The Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983. It also includes consequential amendments to the Broadcasting Act 1942, by omitting of the provisions under which the special broadcasting service is constituted, and to other acts which make reference to the special broadcasting service.
A New Charter

The responsibilities of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation as a national broadcaster are embodied in the charter of the corporation. Honourable senators will be aware that the charter adopted for the corporation in 1983 reflected recommendations arising from a comprehensive inquiry into broadcasting undertaken by a committee chaired by Mr Alex Dix. Whilst the present charter includes a recognition by the corporation of the multicultural character of the Australian community, the Government believes that its objectives for the continuation by the corporation of services currently provided by the special broadcasting service should be reflected in the strengthening of some aspects of the charter.

The strengthening of the charter is to achieve several purposes. Firstly, the government recognises that ethnic radio and multicultural television add a unique element to the Australian broadcasting system. They constitute a recognition of the diversity of the Australian population, and provide practical as well as less tangible benefits to their audiences, such as information on services, educational programming and cultural and linguistic maintenance as well as other assistance. This is of particular importance to many people of non-English speaking background who may rely on these services as the only media accessible to them and in some cases, for example, some new settlers and ethnic aged, their only contact with a community speaking their language or with the broader society.

Educational programming has been an important ongoing responsibility of the ABC. In the same way the SBS has provided valuable educational programs for new settlers, including in helping them to learn English.
Having regard to these valuable elements in the provision of multicultural broadcasting, the Bill includes amendments to the ABC charter which will require the ABC to:
Provide multilingual radio and television programs;
Recognise the need to encourage people whose first language is not English to participate in the political, economic social and cultural life of Australia;
Take account of the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and persons of diverse cultural backgrounds;
Cater for people from non-English speaking backgrounds when providing educational programs, particularly in facilitating the learning of English; and
Take into account Australia's cultural diversity when encouraging and promoting the musical, dramatic and other performing arts.
Consultative Arrangements

Another feature of the legislation which established the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, was that there should be comprehensive arrangements for community consultation and advice to the Board of the Corporation on matters relating to broadcasting programs and television programs. Accordingly, provision was made to establish an advisory council known as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Advisory Council. Provision was also made for the Board of the Corporation to establish advisory councils in relation to any State or to any Territory or in relation to any region of Australia.

In the context of the amalgamation of the two broadcasting organisations, arrangements for consultation will be an important factor in ensuring that the services meet the requirements of the charter and the Government's intentions. The Government considers it essential therefore to ensure the participation in such advisory arrangements by representatives of the broad spectrum of the Australian community, including those who would seek to represent ethnic community interests. Accordingly, the Bill includes a requirement for the Board to recognise the diverse cultural background of the population and to ensure, as far as practicable, that membership of its advisory councils reflects a broad representation of the Australian community, including persons of non-English speaking backgrounds.

I should add that this provision does not preclude the establishment by the Corporation of more specific consultation arrangements where such a need is recognised. For example, I understand that special consultation arrangements have been established in ethnic radio by the SBS to assist its determination of programming directions. I would expect that these sorts of ad hoc arrangements will continue as a means of recognising community interests in specific areas.
Structure of the Board

The broad oversight of policies and operations of both the ABC and the SBS are currently vested in statutorily appointed Boards. The effect of the amalgamation will be to place the responsibility for those functions currently undertaken by the SBS to come within the responsibility of the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The Government takes the view that this substantial change would best be reflected by establishing a new Board. Accordingly, the Bill provides for a Board comprising a Managing Director, a staff-elected Director and up to ten non-Executive Directors. This will result in a Board slightly larger than the current Board of the ABC. It will also enable the membership of the Board to be strengthened to enable it to carry out the wider responsibilities it will assume in relation to ethnic broadcasting under the new structure.

A further provision in the Bill will cause the appointments of all non-Executive Directors, that is those Directors other than the Managing Director, to cease to hold office on the day of amalgamation. New appointments will thus be necessary to form a new Board from 1 January 1987.

I have mentioned that the Board also will continue to include an office of staff-elected Director. In establishing the Corporation in 1983, this Government took the step of ensuring that the interests of staff of the Corporation should be represented on the Board. Such a position was unique in Commonwealth legislation, but recognised the special nature of a body such as the ABC which relies so heavily on the creativity and participation of its staff in achieving its objectives. It is important to note, however, that the occupant of such a position needs to be seen by all staff as representing their interests.

Accordingly, in amalgamating two organisations, the Government believes the opportunity should be provided for all the staff of the organisations to have a say in selecting their representative. The Bill includes, therefore, a provision that a new election is to be conducted as soon as practicable after amalgamation to allow a truly representative staff-elected director to join the new board. To ensure the continuity of representation of staff interests, the Bill provides for the presently identified staff-elected director to remain until a new election is conducted.

The Bill also provides for some consequential amendments to reflect the new board structure. Such matters as quorum levels and provisions for convening of meetings are to be amended by the Bill to reflect the larger board.
Inquiry into Multicultural Broadcasting

In 1984 the government established a committee of review of the Special Broadcasting Service. That committee, chaired by the Honourable Xavier Connor, QC., provided a detailed report to the government and proposed a considerable number of recommendations as to the future form and operation of the special broadcasting service.

Whilst the government has now decided to take a different course to that recommended by the committee as regards structural arrangements, it is important to note that very many of the recommendations put forward by the Connor committee are being reflected in the operations of the special broadcasting service and are proposed to be adopted by the ABC as an integral part of the amalgamation. For example, one of the recommendations of the inquiry was to strengthen the relationship between the then SBS and those services provided by public broadcasting stations.

In recent years the special broadcasting service has established comprehensive co-operative arrangements with public broadcasters for provision of programming and news material to public broadcasting stations around Australia. The Bill includes a specific provision for the corporation to have regard to services provided by holders of public radio licences or public television licences, and establishes a principle that the corporation may provide programs and services to such public licensees. The government is committed to retaining and encouraging the continued development of this relationship with public broadcasters.

Another related recommendation of the Connor inquiry accepted by the government was for the organisation to develop a specific program package for distribution to public broadcasting stations. It was suggested that such a package should consist of national and international news, homeland bulletins, public affairs, settlement and other information, as well as programs in various languages, including English. It was suggested also that such material might be produced by a specialist program packaging unit within the broadcasting organisation. The government continues to support such a proposition and will refer the specific recommendation to the new board of the ABC to consider in the context of its new charter and responsibilities.

At the time of its decision to amalgamate the two organisations, the government had referred some 160 recommendations of the Connor report to the special broadcasting service for decision. Many of those have already been adopted. Notwithstanding the amalgamation decision, the government considers many of those original recommendations to still be appropriate and commendable. Accordingly, the new board of the amalgamated organisation will be asked to consider implementation of a range of those recommendations and to report to the government on progress.
Annual Reporting

The Government is conscious of the concerns expressed by ethnic community representatives that the ABC has not, in the past, given sufficient consideration to ethnic community needs. There are, of course, a number of protections in the Bill to stress the responsibility of the ABC to meet these needs. As a further measure, however, the Bill provides that the ABC is required to specifically include in its annual report to the Parliament, particulars of programs in languages other than English and programs contributing to the development of a multicultural society which it has broadcast or televised during the year to which the report relates. By this means the performance of the organisation in respect of its new responsibilities will be clearly and demonstrably available for public scrutiny.
Transfer of Staff
An important provision of this Bill is for the movement of staff from the SBS to the ABC. It also reflects the requirement to provide protections for the interests of those staff.

The Bill provides that all staff who are, immediately before the amalgamation day, employed by the special broadcasting service, will become either officers or employees respectively of the ABC, depending on their status at the time of amalgamation. The Bill also provides a mechanism for ensuring that terms and conditions of employment of persons who are transferred to the ABC under these provisions are the same as those applying to them before amalgamation. There are, of course, specific provisions under the Public Service Act which offer further protections to staff who, until the amalgamation, have been covered by the Public Service Act. It is expected that the process of integrating the staff of the two organisations will take some time to complete after the amalgamation, but, in this process, there will be full consultation between management, staff and unions.

I should also add that the SBS has been working for some time to achieve a permanent staffing structure for broadcasters and co-ordinators who work in radio stations 2EA and 3EA. I am pleased to say that those agreements which had been reached on a structure will carry over to the new organisation.

Having dealt with the specific provisions of the Bill, I want to repeat to the Senate that the Government is committed to achieving a true amalgamation of the two organisations. It is not, as some would wish to suggest, simply absorbing the SBS into the existing operations of the ABC.

I had indicated earlier that co-ordination arrangements have been established between the Department of Communications, the ABC and the SBS. In pursuance of those arrangements, agreement has already been reached on a new organisation structure to apply after the amalgamation. Under these arrangements, I understand that radio stations 2EA in Sydney and 3EA in Melbourne will be formed into a new division.

With regard to television, the chairman of the ABC has already announced the intention to continue in a clearly separate and identifiable way the television services presently provided by the SBS in parallel with ABC services. SBS television will become known as ABC-1, whereas the existing ABC television services will be known as ABC-2.

The organisational arrangements I have mentioned will ensure the continued separate identity of these services within the ABC. The adoption by the new organisation of these arrangements should also enable the range and type of services that have been available until now from the SBS to be continued. Within these specific and separately identifiable elements the organisation will continue to provide multilingual news services on radio and be able to provide multilingual television news services. Indeed, there is a specific provision in the Bill to ensure the continuation of these services.

Much has been said recently in discussing the pros and cons of amalgamating the two organisations, of the innovative approaches of the SBS in commissioning its programs and in its use of independent producers. Far from constraining such innovative practices, I believe that the amalgamation of the two organisations will promote more efficient and effective arrangements in the new national broadcaster. In addition to economies which will arise from sharing of facilities and accommodation, there will be much greater opportunity for joint purchasing and production of programming and greater complementarity between the services provided. This should ensure, not only the continuation of multicultural programming and services to traditional audiences of the SBS, but allow some proportion of such services to be available to a much wider audience through the extensive ABC network.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TOBACCO INSTITUTE OF AUSTRALIA
Limited (Inc in Vic)

Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Baume

I refer to statements made by you under privilege in the Senate on 22.10.86 and reported in Hansard (pp 1723 & 1724) of that date, in which you made serious accusations against the Tobacco Institute of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. The letter, which deals with certain semantic points as to whether Dr X or some institute said something, completely fails to address the issues we raised. The advertisements I referred to in my questions to Senator Grimes are part of an ongoing campaign orchestrated by the tobacco industry and its specialist lobby group, the Tobacco Institute of Australia, which aims to mislead, to confuse the general public and members of this Parliament about the health dangers of tobacco smoking both to smokers and to non-smokers.

SPEECH.PARA: I was privileged to chair the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare in 1977 which looked specifically at the questions of tobacco as a cause of death in Australia. That Committee reported:

The number of deaths, the morbidity and the misery caused by smoking are very substantial. It is not only that the smoking causes death; it cause many deaths. Cigarette smoking is still as important a cause of death as were the great epidemic diseases of the past.
The Committee also said:

It appears that the fact of tobacco's being dangerous is no longer subject to question in responsible quarters. The Committee rejects the assertions of the tobacco industry that there is no proven relationship between tobacco smoking and ill health.
The Committee in its report further said:
The Committee expresses disappointment that the Australian cigarette manufacturers still do not acknowledge that there is any evidence that tobacco use is a causal factor in ill health.

But that was back in 1977. It appears that there is no longer argument that tobacco smoking is a cause of death. Tobacco kills, and it is now just a matter of defining just how many deaths are caused by smoking tobacco. The Government has released statistics in relation to the so-called drug offensive which have indicated that the death toll from tobacco is of the order of 16,000 Australians per year-from various diseases including lung cancer, heart disease, strokes, chronic bronchitis and emphysema. However, in the Medical Journal of Australia on 7 July this year an article by Dr Darcy Holman and Ms Ruth Shean was published which indicated that the death toll might be more than 46 per cent higher than the Government's figure. That could lead to an annual figure of 23,000 a year.

On 25 September this year, during the hearings of Estimates Committee B, I asked the Minister and, through him, the Department of Health to clarify whether the figure of 16,000 was an underestimate and whether the true figure was closer to 23,000 deaths a year. Let us imagine that 23,000 deaths a year were occurring from some industrial cause or some other public health cause. It would be a scandal. But it is happening from cigarette smoking. At that time the departmental adviser responded by saying that he was not aware of the basis on which the new estimate was derived. I now ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health: Is the true annual mortality figure in Australia due to tobacco smoking around 16,000 a year or is it a higher figure, perhaps closer to 23,000, as indicated by the Medical Journal of Australia on 7 July this year?

The failure of the Government properly to acknowledge the true toll of smoking caused death and disease in this country only continues to serve the tobacco industry's interests by deliberately clouding and confusing the public's mind in regard to the fact that tobacco is the number one cause of preventable death and disease in Australia today. However, the issue for the 1980s is not whether smoking is dangerous to the smoker. That is proven and, by the way, it is a matter for each smoker. I am not trying to stop people smoking on that ground. It is up to them. The new issue is whether smoking is dangerous to the non-smoker-so-called passive smoking.

The question has been researched only relatively recently-say, in the last five to 10 years. Not surprisingly, because of various methodological problems, some of the early studies showed no conclusive effect of tobacco smoke on the health of non-smokers. However, as more studies were conducted, the evidence became more conclusive. The National Heart Foundation of Australia, in its landmark publication last year, entitled `So You Think You're a Non-Smoker?' reviewed all of the published medical evidence to July 1985. The National Heart Foundation concluded:

There is now more than enough health evidence against passive smoking to warrant remedial and preventive action: we recommend that non-smokers play it safe for themselves and their children by taking steps to avoid tobacco smoke wherever possible.

Perhaps the National Heart Foundation is wrong. Perhaps the Tobacco Institute is more knowledgeable. Perhaps there is no risk from passive smoking. But the National Heart Foundation's report was followed by a report of the working party of the NHMRC-the National Health and Medical Research Council of Australia-on the effect of passive smoking on health. This report was adopted at the 101st session of the Council in June 1986. Its conclusions are the same as those of the National Heart Foundation and every other medical authority which has published a major report on this issue. Perhaps the NHMRC is wrong. Perhaps the Tobacco Institute is right. Perhaps there is no risk from passive smoking. But the inhalation of tobacco smoke by non-smokers does pose a risk to their health and a risk of contracting various diseases. The risk is small when compared to the health risks suffered by active smokers. But it is significant, it is measurable and it is an unsolicited risk. Responsible governments should take steps to protect those people in their communities who choose not to have their health damaged by tobacco smoke.

In order to give honourable senators an indication of just how large the risk to the passive smoker is, I would like to consider just one of the diseases-lung cancer. It has been estimated that passive smoking is responsible for the deaths of about 64 Australians from lung cancer each year. Let us just imagine if one consignment of food was contaminated and 64 Australians died. There would be a running scandal in the Press. But we estimate that 64 non-smokers die each year from lung cancer as a result of passive smoking. I am sure honourable senators would agree that this risk is pretty small if one compares that figure to the figure of 3,000 or 4,000 Australians who die from lung cancer each year due to active smoking. However, for the 64 people who did not smoke, who contracted lung cancer from other people's tobacco smoke and who died from lung cancer it was a very significant event.

The important point is: How have the tobacco industry generally and the Tobacco Institute of Australia specifically responded to this mounting medical evidence of the health dangers of passive smoking? They have responded by attempting to confuse the objective scientific debate on this question and deliberately to mislead and confuse the people of Australia. On Tuesday, 1 July 1986 in the Australian newspaper, and in other newspapers on and around that date, the Tobacco Institute lodged an advertisement entitled: `A message from those who do. . . to those who don't'. It talked about cigarette smoking. The advertisement purported to establish that there is little evidence, and nothing which proves scientifically, that cigarette smoke causes disease in non-smokers.

Because the Tobacco Institute of Australia has no credibility with anyone, in this advertisement it drew heavily on the credibility of three major organisations which are well regarded-the Institute of Cancer Research in Surrey, England, the American Cancer Society and the World Health Organisation. I would like to demonstrate to honourable senators how the Tobacco Institute of Australia has used the names of these prestigious organisations in a diabolically misleading manner. I refer first to the Institute of Cancer Research. The tobacco industry's campaign to mislead began with the publication of a report on page 11 of the London Times of 20 June 1986. That report foreshadowed the publication of a research paper in the following month's issue that is, in the July issue, of the British Journal of Cancer. Honourable senators will be aware that this issue of the British Journal of Cancer would have been published in England in July, but it would come to Australia some time later. In fact, the library at the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the Australian National University did not receive that particular issue of the British Journal of Cancer until 16 September. The medical library at the University of Sydney received it on 17 September, and the medical library at the University of Melbourne received it on 24 September.

Notwithstanding the fact that the article was not available in Australia and notwithstanding the fact that it was working from a newspaper report, the Tobacco Institute of Australia rushed into print advertisements which made statements about, and drew conclusions from, the report published in the London Times-not even from the report published in the British Journal of Cancer. It is apparent that the Tobacco Institute did not check the facts before publishing the advertisement. It would seem, given that the issue of the journal which contained the article referred to in the advertisement was not available in Australia until almost three months later, that it sought to establish in the minds of the public the false impression that passive smoking was not dangerous to the health of non-smokers. Ordinarily, its assertions in these advertisements would have gone unchallenged until the report was available in Australia. In the interim, the view which it put forward would have been firmly established in the public's mind. Let us look at what the Tobacco Institute said about the report from the Institute of Cancer Research. It said:

The London Times reported findings from the Institute of Cancer Research in Surrey, England, published in this month's edition of the `British Journal of Cancer,' that `passive smoking' for life-long non-smokers carries no significant increase in the risk of lung cancer, bronchitis or heart disease (all allegedly associated with smoking).
The Institute's conclusions are based on a wealth of statistical detail-
I repeat: A wealth of statistical detail-
from a study involving 12,000 people.

Much weight was placed on the claim that the British study of passive smoking involved 12,000 people. Yet, when one looks at the report, one notes that the findings for lung cancer, upon which the advertisement concentrated, and about which it sought to mislead the Australian public, are actually based on a study of only 47 non-smokers with lung cancer and 96 non-smokers without lung cancer. What is all of this nonsense about 12,000 people? The findings for bronchitis and heart disease are based on even smaller numbers. So of the 12 formal studies on passive smoking and lung cancer that have now been published, this British study is one of the smallest. I have a few more comments to make, but I will yield the floor to another senator. I will resume my remarks when I get the call again.

I do not think the Tobacco Institute knows fact from fiction when it comes to what it is trying to sell. Each of the three doctors I mentioned-Drs Masironi, Weiss and Peto-was forced to write to the Australian newspapers, individually dissociating themselves from the Tobacco Institute advertisement. Each of them pointed out that the paper referred to did not have the endorsement of the Institute of Cancer Research. That does not seem to worry the Tobacco Institute as that was not acknowledged in the letter it wrote to me. The Institute has what in Hebrew is called chutzpah, which roughly defined is that quality--

TALK.START.PARA: —Cheek.

—That is right, the man who murders his parents and throws himself upon the mercy of the court because he is an orphan. It has plenty of chutzpah, even if it does not have much humility or honesty. In addition, Dr Masironi had to correct the references in the advertisement to the World Health Organisation, which was also referred to. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The World Health Organisation rejects the misrepresentation and unauthorised use of its name in the cause of the tobacco industry to downplay the health risks of passive smoking.

At the 77th session of the World Health Organisation executive meeting, held in Geneva in January this year, the World Health Organisation reaffirmed and strengthened its public views of the health dangers of smoking to both smokers and non-smokers.
Perhaps the World Health Organisation is wrong too, along with all the other expert bodies, and perhaps it is only the Tobacco Institute that has it right. He further stated:
The executive board unanimously adopted a resolution which takes a strong position against enforced smoking, which means inhaling other people's smoke.
In the advertisement the Tobacco Institute refers to `the remarks at the conclusion of the 1984 Vienna Health Conference which was held in co-operation with the World Health Organisation.'

Despite what may have been said at the Conference and later by the tobacco industry, the World Health Organisation did not participate or co-operate in the conference in any way, and accordingly statements arising from participants at the conference cannot be construed as being endorsed by the World Health Organisation.
That is because quite clearly the World Health Organisation does not hold the views that the tobacco industry has attributed to it. He went on to say:

The resolution of the executive board of the World Health Organisation is quite explicit. Steps should be taken to `ensure that non-smokers receive effective protection, to which they are entitled, from involuntary exposure to smoke, in enclosed public places, restaurants, transport and places of work and entertainment.

I say to Senator Elstob that that in no way seeks to restrict the right of people to smoke. It merely seeks to ensure the right of other people not to have to inhale other people's smoke. It is most important to note that the Tobacco Institute knew all this information when it published its advertisement. The advertisement not only was misleading but also was deliberately misleading and recklessly incorrect. All this was set out in a WHO Press release of 16 January 1986, of which the Tobacco Institute was aware, yet David Bacon still tried in his letter to me to put forward incorrect and inaccurate information. He should have known from the three sources that it was wrong. He should have known because there was a letter from Dr Wynder of 8 September 1986. He should have known because there was a report back to WHO from a Dr Nedd Willard, an information officer with the WHO who attended the Vienna conference, and he should have known because of the specific refutation of his claims by Dr Robert Masironi published in the Australian Financial Review. In my language this makes the Tobacco Institute a deliberate teller of untruths.

Fortunately, however, action is being taken against the Tobacco Institute. The Advertising Standards Council of Australia has already upheld a complaint against the Tobacco Institute's advertisement. The Advertising Standards Council has found that the Tobacco Institute had breached the advertising code of ethics relating to advertisements being truthful and not misleading or deceptive. That has happened. Again, that does not go to the rights of smokers; it goes to the requirement that advertisers tell the truth. The Tobacco Institute has not. The Trade Practices Commission is continuing its investigations under section 52 of the Trade Practices Act which deals with false and misleading advertising. The Trade Practices Commission has the power to fine an offender or to order corrective advertising. It is reputed that the Tobacco Institute's advertisements in this case cost in excess of $80,000. Given its very substantial budget, I believe it should be forced to spend a similar amount on corrective advertising.

Given the blatant attempt by the Tobacco Institute of Australia to deceive Australians, I invite the Government to set up a full independent inquiry into this incident and into the role of the Tobacco Institute of Australia in deliberately continually misleading people in the pursuit of what is--

—The Minister for Resources and Energy might have a few things to say, but the Tobacco Institute of Australia has proceeded quite recklessly and deliberately to try to mislead the public, and these facts should be made well known to everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask some serious questions about the `new' practice of program budgeting. Whilst I totally approve of program budgeting, which is meant to report on the cost-effectiveness of programs for the community, I find that the reporting the Senate is getting leaves a considerable amount to be desired. In the course of attending Estimates committee meetings I found that the individual detailed departmental bud- gets of no less than eight departments which had moved to program budgeting seemed not to balance with the consolidated figures in Budget Statement No. 6.

I asked the Department of Finance and the individual departments concerned to give me reasons for the lack of reconciliation between the figures. The figures given to me by the Department of Finance were different in various cases from those of the individual departments. This seemed very strange to someone who is used to getting effective answers. Apparently the Department of Finance is recording the information, for which I congratulate it, from departments as it is coded by the departments. Obviously, some departments had re-coded individual items at the lowest level.

Most disturbingly, I was wrong in thinking that two of the departments' figures did not balance. The reason the figures did not balance was that I had failed to take into account the special appropriations associated with those departments. However, I still received a cogent answer from the departments concerned and the Department of Finance and a new, `balancing' figure. But this did not increase my confidence in the figures or in the way this new system is working. One of the main things that give confidence to an accountant is if the figures balance in some way. The amounts involved were not serious. What was serious was that they did not balance.

I believe that the Senate would be much more able to assess Public Service expenditure and the effectiveness of Public Service programs if it were given figures in more than one form. I am quite certain that the previous financial accounting method of producing for us figures for all the expenditure within expenditure categories and all the revenue within revenue categories must be kept in place. I would be most disturbed if the baby were thrown out with the bath water during the process of going over to program budgeting. Some type of reporting in both ways would give the Senate some way of better assessing the figures.

If we want open government and an understanding of how departments are spending their money and what they are spending it on, it is useful to have program budgeting. But it is also useful to know, in breakdown, what money is being spent on consultants, for example, and how those consultants are being used.

When questions were asked of the Department of Finance and a number of other departments relating to individual expenditure categories we found that those figures had been lost somewhere in the process. We could get only broad and somewhat fuzzy answers from the departments. That may be because the departments do not quite understand the processes of reporting. It seems to me that reporting in both ways would be useful-not necessarily deluging us with paper but retaining the previous form of reporting as well as using the new form. Modern technology allows one to report in both ways in general. It is a matter of having a different set of keys on each individual expenditure item and summing them in a different way. It would also be very useful in understanding the rationale and the premises on which budgeting decisions are made. The program budgeting system gives us that type of figure but it is much easier to compare actual expenditure with budgeted expenditure under the previous system. There is obviously a problem with the changeover. I would like some comment from the Department in this area.

The other thing that worried me about the reporting in the program budgeting process is that when I analysed it I found that certain departments which are considered as basically being cost centres, such as the Department of Communications, are not only cost centres. They are predominantly profit centres. They sell off a scarce resource-in this case our airwaves-to the highest bidder. To cut the engineering staff of the Department of Communications in the present business environment is an idiocy, as it also cuts down on its profitability. It just does not make any business sense. The revenue of certain areas of other departments is also higher than their costs. No such marginal analysis seems to have been done. I would like some comment on this matter, if necessary on notice. I found it very difficult, for example, to consider the Department of Housing and Construction. When we looked at it under the program budgeting system it seemed to do very little in some programs. Maybe the Government should be looking at this area.

This is the first year in which the estimates from that Department have been presented on a program by program basis. We no longer have its estimates by expense, but the expenditure still takes place in that Department in the same way. Perhaps other departments have this problem. If the Department of Finance is doing its job-it seems that that is the type of analysis where there is second guessing of the Department by taking the Department's figures and putting them through the computer system of the Department of Finance-it would be very useful if it could do that with both the cost centre type of reporting, which we used to have, and the new program reporting which we now have in the departments which have gone over to program budgeting. I hope that we do not throw out the baby with the bath water. I would find it very useful to have both sets of figures. The cost to the Public Service of getting them should not be very high.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise several matters that arise out of the Estimates committee inquiries and which remain unanswered or perhaps need some comment at this political level. Let me go through just a few of the more innocuous ones to start. First and foremost, in answer to questions on notice put by me, the Australian Taxation Office has replied to a question concerning costs associated with the preparation of an objection to an assessment being tax deductible. Indeed, it will probably come to the attention of people practising in the profession as something of real interest.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point about this question is very important. The Government is now moving into a system of taxation by self-assessment which will obviously mean that there will be a long period when there is considerable doubt about assessments. Assessments will come some time in the indefinite future, no doubt with considerable discussion with the Tax Office as to the correctness of that assessment. Bearing in mind that over time there will be lost records, the need to research problems and to go back over old work, there will undoubtedly be considerable costs associated with assessments and objections on the part of taxpayers as they employ professional advisers in the future. Consequently, this seems to be an extremely unjust proposal in that in future people in that situation apparently will not be able to deduct for tax purposes the cost of doing the work on behalf of the Tax Office to prove that they have paid their full tax assessment. This is a matter of some principle and it is something that needs to be taken up in other forums and other debates. Another matter that also came as a surprise is that if a person seeks to have a taxation appeal referred to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal the $200 that is required to be paid will not be tax deductible. If the appeal is successful there is capacity for it to be refunded. However, there will be considerable concern on the part of taxpayers about the $200 having to be paid up front in these circumstances and that that amount will not be tax deductible either. That is an enormous burden to taxpayers when one considers that, as I have just mentioned, they will also be forced to take care of the non-deductibility of costs associated with objections and professional advice obtained in respect of them.

Another matter that arose during the Estimates committee debate and at earlier times concerns the new procedures now that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will become the body which reviews appeals for tax purposes. In the past the old boards of review used to undertake that task. I am interested in the matter of reasons being given to taxpayers when a decision has been made. I understand that in future the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will not be providing reasons when it makes a decision. I received an answer in writing from the Tax Office on the point I am seeking to make. The reply was as follows:
On every review, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will give a written decision either affirming, varying or setting aside the decision under review.
I would hope so. After all, that is its purpose. The reply continued:
If it sets aside the decision it will either substitute its own decision or remit the matter for reconsideration.
Reference is made to sub-section 43 (1) of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act. The reply continued:
If the Tribunal does not give its reasons in writing a party to the proceeding may, within 28 days of service of the decision, request written reasons which must be provided within a further 28 days.
That is set down in sub-section 43 (2a) of the AAT Act. The reply further stated:
Written reasons must include findings of facts and the material on which those findings were based.

There is a further reference to sub-section 43 (2b) of the AAT Act. While the answer is not as clear as I would have liked it to be, I take it that it indicates that reasons are not generally available to taxpayers in circumstances where their appeals have been heard by the Tribunal. That means that taxpayers will be required to ask for the reasons to be drawn up and presented to them. They have a 28-day period in which to do that and the AAT has a further 28 days in which to set down those reasons and reply.

I hope the importance of giving reasons is obvious to all honourable senators insofar as taxpayers, in order to preserve their rights, ought to have an opportunity of seeing quite clearly the reasons why the AAT has come to its determination in particular circumstances. That would enable the taxpayer to exercise his right to appeal to higher courts in order to have his case heard and obtain justice if he considers that he has not received justice at the AAT level.

The point about reasons is important. I wonder what procedures the Tax Office will be putting in place in order to ensure that this matter is drawn to the attention of taxpayers as and when they submit their appeals to the tribunal so that the 28-day cut-off does not unduly infringe their rights. Quite clearly, given the way in which appeals will no doubt be handled, with advisers and the complications of transfer of information between officers of advisers and officers of the client or the taxpayer concerned and, of course, the Tax Office, 28 days is a relatively short period in which people can exercise their right to obtain reasons and so preserve their rights. I merely want to get clear what the Department will be doing to draw to the attention of taxpayers their rights in these situations so that they will be able to exercise them properly.

I turn to one or two other matters concerning the Department of the Treasury and, in particular, the Tax Office. During the Estimates committee hearing we were very interested in trying to discover the procedures the Department went through in order to try to estimate the amount of tax revenue from the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the disallowance of entertainment expenses as a tax deduction. It is fair to say that we have had some rather inadequate replies. First of all, as far as I can ascertain we have had no reply in respect of the fringe benefits tax, and we have had a very inadequate answer on the disallowance of entertainment expenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that a few of the matters which I raised before the suspension of the sitting and which I will not reiterate will draw some comment from the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). The next matter I would like to raise in respect of the estimates of the Australian Taxation Office is the question of what kind of procedures were adopted by the Department of the Treasury to estimate the net revenue gain from the disallowance of entertainment expenses. During the sittings of the Estimates Committee C I asked officials how they estimated this amount. The key point I wanted to bring out was what allowance had been made in the estimate for the substitution of non-deductible expenditure-that is entertainment-with deductible expenditure of another kind, for instance advertising.

SPEECH.PARA: The point at issue here is simply that, certainly from my experience in talking to businessmen about their plans immediately following the introduction of the legislation last November, it was clear that many expected not to continue to expend money on entertainment but to expend money on other marketing oriented projects, such as advertising, which expenditure would normally be tax deductible. Another instance, of course, might be that they would tend to spend money on overseas travelling expenses in order to promote their businesses and the marketing of their products. In this way they would merely change the emphasis from one category of expenditure to another but, of course, they would still get a tax deduction for the same amount of money. Consequently, the Tax Office will not collect the kind of revenue that it might have expected to receive from non-deductible expenditure because expenditure has been found to be deductible in another way. Apparently, from what I can see from the answer given by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or the Department on this matter, such substitution has not been taken into account and I find that amazing. This would certainly lead us to conclude that the estimate of the Government in respect of entertainment expenses, which was something like a saving of $310m, will be, I think, substantially lower than that when all the numbers are done, quite simply because apparently those substitution factors have not in any way been taken into account in the Department's estimates.

The next area of interest is the way in which the Tax Office calculated the amount of revenue to be gained from the capital gains tax. The answer to this question is really quite interesting. I thank the Tax Office for providing that answer in such detail as it gives us some idea of the way in which the processes within the Tax Office operate. For instance, we tried to estimate the amount of revenue from the capital gains tax by assuming that the Canadian model was a good place to start. Therefore, we assumed that such things as the rate of inflation and the growth rate in the value of real estate and other assets that applied in that country were reasonably expected to be applicable to Australia. The Department admits in its answer that `the methodology is necessarily very coarse'. That would have to be the greatest understatement of all times in terms of how the calculations are in fact addressed in this answer. Nevertheless, the short point to be made is that the Government estimated that in the year ended 30 June 1986 there would be no revenue from the capital gains tax which is, of course, to be expected since the tax would not have been fully in operation for 12 months. In the next year, 30 June 1987, it is also expected that there will be no revenue. In the year ended 30 June 1988 it is estimated that there will be revenue of $5m; in the year ended 30 June 1989, $15m; and in 1990, $25m.

Be that as it may, it is interesting to note that many companies have already given indications to the stock exchange and other places that they expect that their liabilities in respect of the capital gains tax will be several millions of dollars in this first financial year-far in excess of the estimates that were set down in this reply. So quite clearly one has to consider the methodology by which the estimates were made in the first place to be very questionable indeed. This point raises several implications because the Government has been very careful to sell its introduction of this tax on the basis that it was not going to have very much effect either in the money market, the farming areas or other areas. Consequently, any increases in revenue which are expected over and above the amounts which were set down in the original estimates contained in the reform of the Australian taxation system proposals quite clearly are going to change the perception of the electorate about what the Government intended in this area. Quite clearly, the farming community for one might expect a substantially different result from what is expected by the Government and consequently will no doubt have to pay more capital gains tax than it might have been led to believe by this Government.

Yesterday, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), in answer to a question from Senator Black about land values, was keen to make the point when talking about the farming sector that farmers would not suffer substantially from the introduction of the capital gains tax simply because they have, on average, a very substantial equity in their properties. That might be so, but I read in this morning's Daily Telegraph that land prices have crashed in the rural slump in most New South Wales country districts. An article in that newspaper pointed out that the rural industry crisis bites deeper. I would like to make the point that while Senator Walsh and Government senators can stand up here and make the point that on average the farmer will not be affected because over many years the value of farming real estate has not varied significantly above changes in the consumer price index, the point has to be made that when there are severe changes in the economic circumstances of the country and the farming community, people are forced to sell their properties and, consequently, realise the capital gains inherent in those properties at a time when they are least able to defend themselves against economic change. Consequently, they do not conform necessarily with the nice neat average that Senator Walsh and Mr Keating have designed for them. As a result, the profits they make may well be substantially greater than the rate of inflation that might have applied. Everyone knows that land valuations and the valuation of other assets do not move along in some kind of pre-destined orderly pattern of development. They in fact fluctuate very greatly over time. Consequently, farmers in particular will be caught in situations where, because of their cash flow situation, they are forced to realise their properties right at a time when they are least protected by the capital gains tax law as it has been set down by the Government.

I wanted to make a point about the way in which the fringe benefits tax has been levied against the various departments of the Government. It is interesting to note that the Taxation Office is paying some $477,000 to itself as a result of the imposition of the fringe benefits tax. One wonders about the logic or stupidity of such an effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that still correct or have they had to change it again?

—That is the figure I heard of last, but it could possibly have changed since then. Leaving that aside, the point I wanted to make was that clearly it is the wish of the Government that, where fringe benefits are provided to employees-that includes public servants working for the Tax Office-the benefits available to the employees be cashed out and paid in the form of salary increases rather than having them provided in the form of non-cash benefits. If that were so, the public servant or the employee receiving the fringe benefit would of course pay the tax on the benefit that he would receive. SPEECH.PARA: In light of the Government's stated wish in this place, as stated by Senator Walsh during the debate on the legislation when he said that all benefits should be cashed out and paid to the employees rather than maintained as a fringe benefit-that is clearly what the Government was intending by introducing the fringe benefits tax-why is it that the Government does not enforce its own rules upon its own employees and seek to relieve the burden on the taxpayer by making sure that the employee beneficiaries in fact are made to pay the tax that is due on their fringe benefits? We have seen cases where that has affected private sector employees. We note the case of the bank officials, who are kicking up some noise about those very circumstances. They either are having the benefits effectively cashed out or, alternatively, are losing them as a result of employers changing attitudes.
